NEW YORK.

FRIDAY, JUNE 24, 1887.

THE QUEEN'S JUBILEE.

At twelve minutes past two o'clock on the morning of the 29th of June, 1837, died William IV, who seven years before had ascended the throne of Great Britain and Ireland on the death of his brother George IV. It is an axiom of monarchical governments that "the king never dies," and hence the French heralds of the olden time, when one of their monarchs was gathered to his fathers, would say "Vive le Roi et vive le Roi!" Victoria succeeded her uncle King William, and in virtue of this recognized law and custom, her accession to the crown is held to have taken place on the same day as her predecessor's. In point of fact, four hours after the king's death the youthful Princess was roused from her slumber and, before the outside world was aware that the great event had come, was hailed by the Primate of England as Queen of the British dominions. At eleven o'clock the same day (having attained her majority), she formally took the oath to govern according to law, and on the following day her accession to the throne was publicly proclaimed with the usual pomp and ceremony, the coronation taking place nine years after, on the 28th of June, 1838. On the 20th of this present month of June, 1887, our good Queen has thus completed the fiftieth year of her reign, and her Jubilee as sovereign of the British Empire has been celebrated by a loyal and affectionate people in the United Kingdom, in all her colonies and dependencies throughout the world, and in every foreign country where the British race are to be found located.

Victoria Alexandrina is the daughter of Edward Duke of Kent, son of George III and brother of George IV and William IV, and her mother the Duchess of Kent was the daughter of the late Duke of Saxe Coburg. Victoria was born 24th of May, 1819, and her father having died the following year, the Duchess devoted herself to the care and education of her only child with such diligence that she became the example of her honored parents.

The accession of Queen Victoria occurred while Britain was enjoying that era of peace which followed upon the overthrow of the great Napoleon, and continued throughout without interruption till the present time. The British motto now-a-days is "defence not offence," and the race is not fond of using its sword when it can avoid it. It was not always so with them. England and Scotland, which are now so happily one in the bonds of peaceful union, fought stubbornly against each other for centuries. Not until then, but the Prince of Wales, for merry England, borne down Montjoye, St. Denis, on the fields of France. The victories of the Black Prince at Crecy and Poitiers and of that of the field of Agincourt are emblazoned on the roll of fame and the names of Blenheim and Waterloo are amongst the most glorious and momentous that modern history records. These were enough for military renown. But even our Queen's reign, though on the whole peaceful, has again been marked by acts of war and bloodshed. Wars. Asia has seen the glitter of the British banner in Afghanistan and Persia, in China and Burmah, not will the Indian mutiny soon be forgotten.

The dark continent has been the scene of action in Ashantee and Zululand and the Transvaal, in Abyssinia and Egypt. Europe has witnessed the greatest struggle of all in that Crimean campaign that humbled the autocrat of the Russian, and even our own Dominion has not been free from troubles which, fortunately for all concerned, never assumed the proportions of war.

In looking back, however, over the reign of Queen Victoria, and comparing it with former periods of similar duration, we fail to mark the rapid and vast progress and development of the Empire in population as well as in material wealth, in commerce and industry, and above all in peace, prior to her reign; the advance in peace has been as great as in war. Space will not permit us even to glance at the principal events in the domestic history of the Empire during the last fifty years, but suffice it to say that the period has produced so many great and good men as the Victorian era is indeed a prolific mine for the future historian to work, and the more so because of some of the more prominent names sufficiently indicating the extent and power, the philanthropy and genius that have been at work for the moral and welfare of their race. In such men as Peel and Wellington, Lord Colborne and Bright, Lord Palmerston, Disraeli and Gladstone, one recognizes statements of the highest order. At the mention of Bristow and Faraday, Murchison and Herschel, Darwin and Hussey, we think of the mighty discoveries and inventions of the Victorian years. That art has suffered no neglect the names of Wilkie and Chantrey, Turner and Landseer, Millais and Ruskin are sufficient proof. In literature, Wordsworth and Southey, Dickens and Tennyson, while they stand out among the poets of their own time, take a high rank among the sweet singers of all ages, and history has never found more illustrious names than those of Lamartine and Grote, Macaulay and Hallam, Froude and Freeman.

In fiction, Bulwer-Lytton and Dickens, Thackeray and George Eliot have been equally richly endowed in raising the standard to the highest. A great literary teaching agent, and such writers as Carlyle and J. S. Mill, Buckle and Matthew Arnold among secular writers, and Chalmers, Irving, Newmann, Macaulay, Coleridge and Sidney Smith, have been the theologians and historians whose labors during the period under review show that the British mind has been actively and energetically engaged.

In colonial affairs the Confederation of the Canadian Provinces, the transfer of the Hudson Bay Territory to the Dominion, the extension of the railway up of the Northwest Territories and the construction of the Canadian Pacific Railway, the opening of the Suez Canal, the settlement of the question of the Northwest Coast and the conclusion of the treaty with the Indians, are amongst the most momentous and significant events in the history of the Empire. Possibly this question may in the near future assume the importance of great national interest, and the question of the rights of the Indians, the fear the idea has created by Prince Albert's visit to the other side of the Atlantic, the White Eagle's breaking race, Benjamin Franklin's Canada, the discovery of the region of utopian dreams, the publication of do not frequently happen in the walk of life, but they are expected to happen. Our history records only three previous instances of monarchs reigning for sixty years. Elizabeth I reigned thirty-five years, James I thirty-eight years, and Queen Victoria thirty-two years. Great Britain and George III the Queen's grandfather, who reigned fifty-nine years, has become noteworthy, but we hope the accession of Queen Victoria has a stronger incentive to replace our present anxieties.

The Editor of the Times

South Africa. In his last issue of The Times I was very much surprised at the article by Mr. Craig regarding the use of barley as a cereal grain by Mr. Wu, now well-known throughout the country. It is difficult to imagine any one else who could have written such an article.

Second Gem

To the Editor of The Times:

Last week's article on barley was well-written and thoroughly researched, as was the article about Mr. Wu by Mr. Craig. However, there seems to be a misunderstanding regarding the use of barley as a cereal grain. Mr. Craig's argument seems to be quite logical and convincing.

Yours Truly,

John McCafferty
